alert.note: Alert for Kent (Michigan) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued April 06 at 10:47AM EDT until April 10 at 6:00AM EDT by NWS Grand Rapids
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Michigan... Grand River at Ionia affecting Ionia County. Grand River at Lansing affecting Ingham County. Grand River at Robinson Township affecting Ottawa County. Grand River at Lowell affecting Kent County. Grand River at Ada affecting Kent County. Grand River at Grand Rapids affecting Kent County. Muskegon River at Bridgeton affecting Newaygo County. Maple River at Maple Rapids affecting Clinton County. ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Michigan... Sycamore Creek At Holt affecting Ingham County. Thornapple River Near Caledonia affecting Kent County. Muskegon River at Newaygo affecting Newaygo County. .One to two inches of rain has fallen during the past 36 hours and will take a few days to flow from the tributaries into the river. Generally dry weather is expected during the next week. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT FROM FRIDAY AFTERNOON TO MONDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Grand River at Grand Rapids. * WHEN...From Friday afternoon to Monday morning. * IMPACTS...At 18.0 feet, Expect minor flooding of basements in low lying areas in Grand Rapids. Moderate flooding of homes and structures occurs upstream at Comstock Park and downstream in Robinson Township. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:00 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 16.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage early tomorrow afternoon to a crest of 18.8 feet Saturday morning. It will then fall below flood stage Sunday evening. - Flood stage is 18.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 18.8 feet on 03/19/1982. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/grr.
